thread.title: Saints drop four turnovers, lose 39-17 in Philly
thread.title_full: Saints drop four turnovers, lose 39-17 in Philly - FOX 8 WVUE New Orleans News, Weather, Sports, Social

author: Written by: Sam Winstrom, Assignment Editor
title: Saints drop four turnovers, lose 39-17 in Philly
text:
NEW ORLEANS (WVUE) - The defense forced turnovers and pressured the quarterback, but the Saints couldn't put together a complete game against the Eagles.
The Saints fell to 1-4 after a 39-17 loss to the Eagles Sunday afternoon in Philadelphia.
The Saints started out strong, holding the Eagles to just 10 points in the first half by forcing two well-timed turnovers in the end zone.
The Saints and Eagle traded punts to start off the first quarter, but on their second possession of the game Eagles QB Sam Bradford drove down the field thanks to a few well placed passes. After an 18-yard pass play that put the Eagles into the red zone, Bradford looked to Riley Cooper only to find Saints corner Brandon Browner.
Browner, one of the Saints key off-season signings, pulled in the teams first interception in the end zone for a touchback.
Drew Brees then lead the team on an 80-yard touchdown drive, hitting receivers Willie Snead and Brandin Cooks for key gains before finding Tight End Benjamin Watson for the score, giving the Saints a 7-0 lead that they would carry into the second quarter.
The Eagles offense shook off their turnover and picked up right where they left off, marching down the field and back into the redzone, but once again, Bradford was picked off.
Delvin Breaux, another corner starting his first season with the Saints, picked off a pass intended for Miles Austin and silenced the crowd at Lincoln Financial Field.
The Eagles would not be denied much long though. After forcing a Saints three-and-out, Sam Bradford found receiver Josh Huff for a 41-yard touchdown tying the game at 7-a-piece.
Both defense would hold for the rest of the half until the a Drew Brees fumble within the two-minute warning set up the Eagles for a field goal as the clock expired.
Unfortunately, that wasn't the last fumble of the game for the Saints. Brees would fumble the ball one more time and recent addition Michael Hoomanawanui would lose the teams third. Brees would add an interception as well, bringing the saints to four turnovers on the day.
Philadelphia took advantage of nearly every one of those turnovers to put up 29-points in the second half and bury the Saints 39-17.
Brees put up 335 yards passing and a touchdown, but the team's turnovers were too much to overcome. The Eagles put up 519 total yards on offense.
